COLLEGE FRATERNITIES—

There has been a good deal of misunderstanding in the minds of undergraduates with regard to the changes
in athletic set-up and in the sum of
their tuition, as announced by the
administration during the last academic year.
Omicron Delta Kappa, in an effort to explain the point of view of
the Administration and to clear up
undergrachiate uncertainity, on Wednesday dif,cussed the matters both of
tuition and of athletics with President
Ames.
In the first place it seemed clear
that students believed the University
was getting more money from undergraduate tuition than formerly
and that $10 of each student's tuition was being spent for athletics
Both
and activities, respectively.
beliefs are false. The change to $450

per man has not increased the total
receipts from undergraduate tuition
received by the University. Dr. Ames
pointed out that the system of charging extra fees for laboratories (which
Hopkins gave its students before any
other institution in the country) was
purely a device for increasing income. The recent change was made
because Dr. Ames considered the fee
system discriminatory and a subterfuge; as far as the University is concerned, all undergraduates have the
same privileges and, taken on the
average, cost the same.
It must be understood, furthermore,
that fixed portions of tuitions will no
longer be alloted to activities and
athletics. Complaints have been heard
about the fact that non-athletic activities are receiving no larger amount

Politician and academician met in
a sham political battle this week,
and when the firing of ballots had
finally ceased and the smoke of
counting and recounting had passed
away, it developed that the academician possessed as much ammunition
as the favored politician.

There comes a time in every
man's life when he sees red. So
it happened yesterday in the case
of one of our ultra-Liberal students, who was strolling serenely
around the campus with a copy
of New Masses, Communist periodical, tucked under his arm.
A friend approached, saw only
the word "masses," which was
in massive type, and queried:
"Is that a Catholic magazine?"
Yes, sir, he saw red!

Figures given for the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine list 274 for
the 1934 year as compared with last
year's 283 men.
In the School of Hygiene this year
are entered 89 men. This represents
a decrease of thirteen students over
the 1933 figure of 102.

Undergraduates Decline Slight
For the undergraduate schools the
latest enlistment puts the number at
869 men. Last year the registration
to the same date comprised 875 men,
Which represents a slight decrease
of 6 students this year. However,
the College of Arts and Sciences
gained with a mark of 489 to date
as compared to last year's 466. The
other undergraduate schools show
291 for the School of Engineering
and 89 for the School of Business
Economics. Last year the mark was
School of Engineering, 303; and the
School of Business Economics, 106.
According to Miss Irene Davis, assistant registrar, the geographical
survey has not been made up yet and
will not be released for quite some
time.

Dr.Corwin Will Talk
ToOhioPhysicsClub
Dr. Alsoph H. Corwin, associate
chemistry at the Hopkins, is
scheduled to be a guest speaker at
the fall meeting of the Central Ohio
Physics Club, to be held Saturday,
October 27, at Marietta College.
Dr. Corwin, one of the twelve
Speakers invited from many colleges in the country, will deliver a
talk on the design and construction
of micro-balances entitled "How to
Weigh a Piece of Glass." The speech
will be in connection with the club's
Program "The Relationship of Physics to Industry".
Dr. Corwin is in charge of the
routine laboratory work in advanced
organic chemistry.

Gentleman, Scholar, And
Athlete -Now Coach

MALLONEE
Gardner Mallonee, coach of class
lacrosse under the intra-mural program, has been one of the most
prominent athletes ever produced at
the Hopkins. Born in 1903 in this
city, "Gard" has been associated
with athletics from his "teens" up to
the present time. At the Polytechnic
Institute he starred in football, basketball, and baseball. He made the
All-Maryland High School Football
Team at Poly for two years playing
end. He was a three-letter man
there.

A dormitory ping-pong tournament
is now being run, with 34 players
participating in an attempt to win
the championship of the dorms. Pingpong is having a revival on the campus, and several clubs have been organized to compete against each
other. If enough players show interest, a general league will be
formed at Hopkins.
Regular sports classes for the
freshmen have started. Each new
student is taking physical education
two hours a week. An ambitious
schedule has been organized, as it is
planned to introduce the frosh to every varsity and intramural sport. The
program will be greatly enhanced by
the opening of the new gymnasium,
a project that will probably occur
during the middle of next week.

George Ekaitis' Washington College gridders move in on Homewood
tomorrow still shooting for victory
over the Blue Jays, an object which
has been eluding them regularly
these last few years. The opening
shot will be fired at 2 p. m.
The 'Shoremen come to town a
heavy, aggressive bunch, holding a
51-to-0 decision over Gallaudet in
their only start, last week. They are
adequately equipped at all points.
With the exception of Ford, at right
guard, and Hoffman, at fullback, the
starting combination will be Comprised solely of seasoned performers.
In view of this, the Chestertown followers are sold in the belief that this
is their year to pluck the Blue Jays'
feathers, and a sizeable contingent
of them is crossing the bay hoping
to see just that.
Jays Will Pass
Inasmuch as Washington resembles Lehigh in the matter of line
power, Ray Von Orman, Jay mentor
will, in all likelihood, resort to the
same methods of attack he put into
play against the Garnets last weekend, which is synonymous with saying that the Jays will pass. Ekaitis
has developed a rugged forward wall
which averages slightly better than
190 pounds and proved to be an unusually stubborn unit against Gallaudet.
The 'Shoremen's strong point in the
line is Lord, who is rounding out his
third season as the Red and Black
center. Husky and unusually mobile
for one of his dimensions, he heads
the forwards. Dwyer and Baker, at
the tackles, are much improved over
last year and are cavorting in fine
style.
Tignor's running mate at
guard, Ford, is a newcomer but is
coming along fast and fits in well.
Biancioni and Baker, at the flanks,
are an adept pair and will, undoubtedly, prove troublesmoe to the Jays'
passing and punt-returning activities.
Backfield Has Drive
Hoffman, the only reaclpement in
the backfield, is a big fullback who
can plow through a line, giving the
Shoremen the drive they so noticeably lacked last year. Greims, quarterback, and Berry and Nicholson
disported against Hopkins last fall.

Pasarew, Phillips and Giardini gave
the Jays an edge over Lehigh in line
play, crashing through time and
again to nip Garnet offensive attempts. Pasarew and Billy Van Orman will be at the ends in tomorrow's
tilt, with Ellis and Orth at the tackles, Giardini and Phillips, at the
guards, and Halibert at the snapperback post. Kelly and Zerilli acquitted themselves well in a running and
plunging way against Lehigh, and
will be at the halves. Graziano, who
scored the Jay touchdown on a pass
from McClean, will start at fullback, with the latter calling signals
from quarterback.

COLLEGE FRATERNITIES—

There has been a good deal of misunderstanding in the minds of undergraduates with regard to the changes
in athletic set-up and in the sum of
their tuition, as announced by the
administration during the last academic year.
Omicron Delta Kappa, in an effort to explain the point of view of
the Administration and to clear up
undergrachiate uncertainity, on Wednesday dif,cussed the matters both of
tuition and of athletics with President
Ames.
In the first place it seemed clear
that students believed the University
was getting more money from undergraduate tuition than formerly
and that $10 of each student's tuition was being spent for athletics
Both
and activities, respectively.
beliefs are false. The change to $450

per man has not increased the total
receipts from undergraduate tuition
received by the University. Dr. Ames
pointed out that the system of charging extra fees for laboratories (which
Hopkins gave its students before any
other institution in the country) was
purely a device for increasing income. The recent change was made
because Dr. Ames considered the fee
system discriminatory and a subterfuge; as far as the University is concerned, all undergraduates have the
same privileges and, taken on the
average, cost the same.
It must be understood, furthermore,
that fixed portions of tuitions will no
longer be alloted to activities and
athletics. Complaints have been heard
about the fact that non-athletic activities are receiving no larger amount

Figures given for the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine list 274 for
the 1934 year as compared with last
year's 283 men.
In the School of Hygiene this year
are entered 89 men. This represents
a decrease of thirteen students over
the 1933 figure of 102.

Undergraduates Decline Slight
For the undergraduate schools the
latest enlistment puts the number at
869 men. Last year the registration
to the same date comprised 875 men,
Which represents a slight decrease
of 6 students this year. However,
the College of Arts and Sciences
gained with a mark of 489 to date
as compared to last year's 466. The
other undergraduate schools show
291 for the School of Engineering
and 89 for the School of Business
Economics. Last year the mark was
School of Engineering, 303; and the
School of Business Economics, 106.
According to Miss Irene Davis, assistant registrar, the geographical
survey has not been made up yet and
will not be released for quite some
time.

Dr.Corwin Will Talk
ToOhioPhysicsClub
Dr. Alsoph H. Corwin, associate
chemistry at the Hopkins, is
scheduled to be a guest speaker at
the fall meeting of the Central Ohio
Physics Club, to be held Saturday,
October 27, at Marietta College.
Dr. Corwin, one of the twelve
Speakers invited from many colleges in the country, will deliver a
talk on the design and construction
of micro-balances entitled "How to
Weigh a Piece of Glass." The speech
will be in connection with the club's
Program "The Relationship of Physics to Industry".
Dr. Corwin is in charge of the
routine laboratory work in advanced
organic chemistry.

Gentleman, Scholar, And
Athlete -Now Coach

MALLONEE
Gardner Mallonee, coach of class
lacrosse under the intra-mural program, has been one of the most
prominent athletes ever produced at
the Hopkins. Born in 1903 in this
city, "Gard" has been associated
with athletics from his "teens" up to
the present time. At the Polytechnic
Institute he starred in football, basketball, and baseball. He made the
All-Maryland High School Football
Team at Poly for two years playing
end. He was a three-letter man
there.

A dormitory ping-pong tournament
is now being run, with 34 players
participating in an attempt to win
the championship of the dorms. Pingpong is having a revival on the campus, and several clubs have been organized to compete against each
other. If enough players show interest, a general league will be
formed at Hopkins.
Regular sports classes for the
freshmen have started. Each new
student is taking physical education
two hours a week. An ambitious
schedule has been organized, as it is
planned to introduce the frosh to every varsity and intramural sport. The
program will be greatly enhanced by
the opening of the new gymnasium,
a project that will probably occur
during the middle of next week.

George Ekaitis' Washington College gridders move in on Homewood
tomorrow still shooting for victory
over the Blue Jays, an object which
has been eluding them regularly
these last few years. The opening
shot will be fired at 2 p. m.
The 'Shoremen come to town a
heavy, aggressive bunch, holding a
51-to-0 decision over Gallaudet in
their only start, last week. They are
adequately equipped at all points.
With the exception of Ford, at right
guard, and Hoffman, at fullback, the
starting combination will be Comprised solely of seasoned performers.
In view of this, the Chestertown followers are sold in the belief that this
is their year to pluck the Blue Jays'
feathers, and a sizeable contingent
of them is crossing the bay hoping
to see just that.
Jays Will Pass
Inasmuch as Washington resembles Lehigh in the matter of line
power, Ray Von Orman, Jay mentor
will, in all likelihood, resort to the
same methods of attack he put into
play against the Garnets last weekend, which is synonymous with saying that the Jays will pass. Ekaitis
has developed a rugged forward wall
which averages slightly better than
190 pounds and proved to be an unusually stubborn unit against Gallaudet.
The 'Shoremen's strong point in the
line is Lord, who is rounding out his
third season as the Red and Black
center. Husky and unusually mobile
for one of his dimensions, he heads
the forwards. Dwyer and Baker, at
the tackles, are much improved over
last year and are cavorting in fine
style.
Tignor's running mate at
guard, Ford, is a newcomer but is
coming along fast and fits in well.
Biancioni and Baker, at the flanks,
are an adept pair and will, undoubtedly, prove troublesmoe to the Jays'
passing and punt-returning activities.
Backfield Has Drive
Hoffman, the only reaclpement in
the backfield, is a big fullback who
can plow through a line, giving the
Shoremen the drive they so noticeably lacked last year. Greims, quarterback, and Berry and Nicholson
disported against Hopkins last fall.

Pasarew, Phillips and Giardini gave
the Jays an edge over Lehigh in line
play, crashing through time and
again to nip Garnet offensive attempts. Pasarew and Billy Van Orman will be at the ends in tomorrow's
tilt, with Ellis and Orth at the tackles, Giardini and Phillips, at the
guards, and Halibert at the snapperback post. Kelly and Zerilli acquitted themselves well in a running and
plunging way against Lehigh, and
will be at the halves. Graziano, who
scored the Jay touchdown on a pass
from McClean, will start at fullback, with the latter calling signals
from quarterback.

The interclass soccer

league is ready to start, while there
will also be outside competition to
spur the players on to better efforts.
Yesterday the freshmen and sophomores engaged in an encounter with
Park School, both classes playing
half the game. The varsity is practicing on the lower field near Levering every Tuseday and Thursday
and a home-and-home match with
the State Normal School is already
definitely scheduled.
